From 1859 to 1862
No 2

Image
Deschutes River Sunday September 2d A.D. 1860
1860
Wind high L.L. Williams
L.L.W Del
Image

10
Journal from Elkton to the Mouth of Rogue River in the summer of 1859 by L.L. Williams; Elkton, the County seat of Umpqua County in the State of Oregon, is to be seen only as a precinct, extending along the Umpqua River for the distance of about fifteen miles. A town has been surveyed off upon the west side of the Elk Creek, for the County seat, but as yet there are no public buildings, or buildings of any kind upon it Elkton derives its name from Elk Creek a stream of some 30 yds in width, which empties in to the Umpqua upon the North side, at a distance of fifty miles from its mouth and twenty from Scottsburg the head of navigation, also the head of Tide water upon said River Elk Creek derives its name from the numerous bands of Elk, that ranged upon its banks, and the open praries and bald hills in its vicinity, previous to the valley being settled by the whites This part of the Umpqua Valley was settled about the year 1850, and for farming and grazing purposes, it cannot be surpassed by any other part of Southern Oregon. It is a rolling country, prarie and timber, with handsome River bottoms of farming, land not excelled by any other locality in Oregon

12
July 13th
Left Elkton for Scottsburg, twenty miles distant, where I arrived at 12 M.  The Road from Elkton to this place, passes through prarie Country and keeps in the immediate vicinity of the River. All the open land is claimed and occupied by farmers 

  As you reach within two miles of Scottsburg the Road enters heavy timbered land, which continues to Scottsburg, the head of navigation upon the Umpqua River. 
  The timbered River Bottoms are generally covered with a thick growth of Myrtle, Maple with occasionally Alder, Ash & Willow, Cottonwood.
  Scottsburg is a dull place, consisting of one Store, Hotel and Black smith shop and nearly twenty empty buildings that are fast going to decay.
  In 1850 & 51 this place bid fair to be the most flourishing town in Oregon, lots ranged high, buildings could scarcely be put up as fast as they were demanded by the traders who were every day arriving from the diferent [sic] parts of the Country to engage in business. At that time all the trade of Southern Oregon & Northern California bid fair to be shipped to this post. But AD1833 a Road was opened through the Coast Mountains, from the mining country to a point on the Pacific that proved to be very much nearer than to this place, where a town was soon built up, and

11
aside from these rich bottom lands the open prarie country generally extends back to the hills, and forms what is termed "second bench land" which produces excellent grain but not as rich, or as good for garden vegetables as the River bottoms. And still further back are the high "Bald Hills" which furnish to the agricultural community an excellent range for their stock. these hills are in places very much cut up with Cañons and timbered gulches, and in many places may be found ledges and high cliffs of rock principally sand rock, which appears to be about the only formations (Geologcally) in this vicinity, although in the gravel beds bordering the rivers, may be found pebbles of volcanic, slate & quartz, that have rolled on together into one common deposit

  The timber is principally fir, with quite an abundance of white & black Oak growing upon the borders of the praries and upon the ridges. Cedar is found in the Cañons, and Laurel and a variety of small shrubbery in the Mountains 
  Game is abundant, such as Deer, Bear Geese, Ducks, Grouse, Pheasants, Pigeons Quails &c, Elk may be found quite plenty, within five or ten miles of the settlements, they confine themselves principally to the Mountains. Beaver and Otter and fish of various kind are found in the Rivers

14
Cañons down which are numerous Cascades and waterfalls, roaring and leaping from rock to Crag, forming scenery, picturesque and beautiful in the extreme

  As the Boat reaches a point about five miles from the "Lower Town" the River is divided by a small low grassy Island into two Channels, the left Channel is only one used for navigation, and in this the water is shoal, not over one or two feet in depth at low tide. This shoal is called "Brandy Bar" and is the only obstruction to navigation from the Ocean to Scottsburg 
  At high tide there is from six, to ten feet water on this bar, rendering safe navigation to River Streams or small Schooners. At this place the banks become less rocky, and you will notice a change in timber which is principally Spruce, growing upon low wet and swampy ground along the margin of the River
  At 18 miles from Scottsburg you pass the mouth of "Smiths River" a stream of about 100 yds in width, entering the Umpqua from the North, this River is navigable for River Steamers about 25 miles and for row boats some ten or twelve miles further to the head of tide water upon said stream
  There are a few settlers upon it, but not a country to ever be very thickly populated 
  It runs through a high mountain Range

13
named Crescent City, from the Crescent shape of its harbor or Roadstead upon which it is built, since the locality of this town, the most of the mining trade has been shipped there, consequently a nearly fatal blow to Scottsburg

  Scottsburg is named after its proprietor Capt Levi Scott, one of the pioneers of Oregon, who has gained the title of Capt during some of the early Indian wars

July 13th

  Took passage down River on board the Steamer "Sattelite", a pretty little Steamer for River or Bay navigation, and able to run at the rate of 15 miles per hour 
  One half mile below the town we passed a Sawmill upon the right bank. At the mouth of a rapid little Mountain stream of about 50 ft in width. And 1 1/2 miles farther passed what is denominated the "lower town", a place of 12 or 15 houses that were hastily put up when times were flourishing, in opposition to Scottsburg proper 
  These buildings are all vacated, and no business done here at all.
  The "lower town" or "Lower Scottsburg" is the terminus of the River bottoms, and for about five miles farther the River is walled in with perpendicular walls and craggy escarpments of Sand Rock of two or three hundred feet in height cut up into chasms and deep narrow

16
Gardner, was also settled in 1850 and contains only one house

  About two miles below "Gardner" as the River turns to nearly a South Course, you have a fair view of Fort Umpqua and its adjacent buildings, situated in the drifting sand & just in the borders of a grove of spruce pine timber, a species of scrub pine, peculiar to a barren sandy soil
  After making the turn to the Southward the River runs paralel to the Coast (which is not over two or three miles off) for seven or eight miles forming a chain of drifting sand hills, interspersed with occasional groves and scattering spruce pine trees. These sand hills are composed of the white sand peculiar to the sea Coast, and are drifted in many places to the height of 100 feet
  Amongst this sand stands Fort Umpqua six miles from "Gardner" where we stopped for the night. At this place is an agency and Indian Reservation, upon which are collected the Umpqua & Coos Bay Indians numbering some two hundred, and are fed and cared for by the U.S. Government
  The opposite side of the River from the Fort consists of low mountains heavily timbered with Fir, Spruce, Hemlock Cedar &c

July 14th

  The Boat got under way and after a run of six miles I was landed on the south side of

15
with only small narrow bottoms of land suitable for cultivation. In the mouth of Smith River is "Boldens Island" which appears to be a detached mountain of about 100 ft in height heavily timbered with fir, and about one half mile in length. The main Umpqua and the largest part of Smiths River passes to the left of the Island 

  Smiths River is named from Capt Smith an early Trapper and fur trader who crossed the continent via the Colorado River & explored the Coast from the Gulf of California to this place, where his company were all killed by the Indians except himself and one or two others, who at that time happened fortunately to be seperated from the balance
  After the loss of his company, he fled through the Mountains and joined the "N.W. Fur Company" on the Columbia River and was afterwards killed by the Indians somewhere in the New Mexican Country
  Passing the lower extremity of "Boldens Island" you have a fair view of Gardner City. The Port of Entry to the Umpqua River was settled in 1850 and as yet contains but one house and a Ware House & wharf
  At this place the River expands to about one mile in width with a few low marshy Islands near the south shore and a marshy border on the north
  The City of Providence is situated on the South side of the River opposite

18
while below high water mark it is hard & solid, so much so that horses leave scarcely a print of their feet.

  Fortunately for me the Tide was on the ebb consequently first rate travelling 
  At ten miles from the mouth of Umpqua a stream of some twenty feet in width breaking through the sand hills into the Ocean. This is called "ten mile creek", being equal distant from Umpqua & Coos Bay and the only fresh water between the two places
  It is also the County line between the two Counties of Umpqua & Coose 
  Pasing [sic] this Stream about five or six miles, then bore off to the left, over the loose sand; about one mile to the beach of "Coose Bay", which like the Umpqua turns to the South at this place, running along paralel [sic] to the Coast from seven or eight miles to its mouth, thus forming a narrow range of low drifting Sand hills betwixt the Bay & Ocean 
  As I approached the Bay, "Empire City" the County Seat of Coose County loomed up magnificently upon the opposite side of the Bay & two or three miles farther down
  A pretty good quality of grass bordering the Bay, through which a good trail led down to the Ferry landing opposite the City. I hoisted the Signal flag at the Ferry landing in accordance with

17
of the River about one half mile from its mouth. The River at the Bar, at low tide is about one fourth of a mile in width

  About 200 yds from the beach stands the Light House, a magnificent building erected during the Summer of 1857
  The Bar at the mouth of the River is a bad one, and many vessels were lost upon it during the first five or six years of the settlement of this part of the Coast 
  But of late, since the pilots have become better acquainted with the Channel and character of the winds and tide, the people of this place have not had occasion to record the loss of a single Vessel
  Here upon this Coast and among the Sand hills and along the Rivers and Bays, may be seen the remains of the deserted Ranches of the Umpquas a once numerous Tribe from which the River takes it name 
  From this, my course was South along the beach, which is wholly composed of Sand, with drifting sand hills to your left, which extend from one to two miles back, and the raging billows continually tumbling and surging, to your right 
  By far the best travelling is when the tide is ebbing for the sand above high water mark, is generally of a drifting nature, causing very laborious travelling

20
large investments necessary to the construction of such buildings

  The shipping to this place is very limited, although there is a good entrance and a beautiful harbor the bay being about one mile in width. The Country around about is not very mountainous, but very heavily timbered
  I was obliged to stop here for the night, not being able to reach the next settlement on the Coquille to day
  July 15
      Left Empire City this morning the trail, led off directly from the Bay, into a heavily timbered Country, of Spruce, Hemlock Fir &c,  with a thick undergrowth of Salmon Berry brush, which at this time were loaded with berries. The timber, particularly the Spruce, grows to a great height, of perhaps 250 or 300 ft, and from 8 to 10 ft in diameter
  About four miles from the Bay you enter forest that is composed wholly of dead timber, caused by fires which to all appearance, had raged fearfully at some late period. In this burnt land the trail was much obstructed by fallen timber, amongst which Blackberry Briers grew to such an extent, as to render the travelling almost anything but agreeable.
  About two and one half miles after you enter the burnt timber, you ascend

19
instructions which were posted in a conspicuous place, and had the satisfaction of seeing the Boat got under way, and in a short time I was landed on the opposite side in the suberbs [sic] of the City

  This Bay & vicinity was settled in 1853, during a great excitement, upon the discovery of extensive Coal beds in the neighborhood and rich placers of Gold on the beach; Empire City is the principal place, was (like thousands of other towns on this coast) built up in a hurry and died out as suddenly, it contains about twenty five houses, and not over five or six that are at present occupied, the remainder fast going to decay, in consequence of the Gold mines proving a failure and the Coal Banks not proving to be a paying institution
  The Coal mines are still worked to some little extent, but are yielding but little encouragement. Although Coal is abundant, yet its quality and the cost of labor, shipment &c does not justify the proprietors of the "Beds" to drive the business very extensively
  A large Steam Saw Mill upon the upper border of the town, and another some few miles up the Bay, have been quite extensively engaged in the manufacture of lumber for the past two or three years but at the present time are motionless doing nothing, and apparently not paying a very heavy interest upon the

22
but was killed near them, a limb of the tree passing through her head and penetrated the ground, she was very much mangled.
The youngest was in its mothers arms when the sad catastrophy took place, and that noble parent was heard to say, (after four corpses
had been recovered from the ruins) "thank God, my babe is spared to me" and at the same time it was a corpse in her arms, a small limb
had cut through its head, and its brain was dripping from the wound, and it  was carried about for some little time before any one present was conscious of its death.

              You pass the house about twenty yards, and there to the left of the trail about one hundred and twenty five yards among the dead timber, somewhat overgrown with briers, you can see the graves of the poor little unfortunates, where the five sisters are now sleeping the quiet sleep of

death.  Around the graves is a paling fence partially thrown down by a small tree falling against one corner of it.
[drawing of the graves labeled The graves]

         What sight can be more painful or more melancholy, than the graves

21
ascend a gentle rise which continues for about one fourth of a mile. when you arrive at the ruins of a deserted house, at one time during the first settlement of this part of the Coast was occupied by a family by the name of Yocum and in this family, on the 26th day of March 1855, there happened one of the most heart rending calamities, that ever  befel any family upon this Coast. It was caused by a large spruce tree, of huge dimensions, falling upon the house, killing five little girls, daughters of Mr Yocum, the oldest fourteen years old and the youngest a child in its mother arms         It appears that the tree had been set on fire some time previous to the accident and several times during the day the family had left the house for safety, when just in the dusk of the evening, the tree fell with a terible [sic] crash upon the house, hastening the five little innocents into eternity, while the brokenhearted parents, and two little boys were spared to mourn over the mangled corpses of their Children and sisters. The two little boys were asleep in one extreme corner of the house and were uninjured, and what is much more strange, were not awakened until searched for as among the dead, Mr. Y. being outside the house discovered the dang[er] and gave the family warning, but alas it was to [sic] late. The oldest girl, hearing her fathers warning, with a heroic courage rushed forward to save her little brothers

23
of five little sisters, killed by an accident of the most horrible kind, lying side by side in the midst of a thick forest,  far from the residence of any human beings and those that were near and dear to them compelled to leave them in their lone resting place, there to remain until the grave shall give up its dead, The tears of agony that were shed over those mortal remains and around these graves have been sufficient to move the hardest of hearts, and many has been the tear that has fell from the eyes of strangers and lone travellers, while contemplating the sad events that hastened those dear beloved little children into the presence of their God. 

     After spending about one hour around this little grave yard, contemplating the sad event, I again started on my course through the same kind of burnt wood for about seven miles farther, when the trail entered a gigantic growth of green timber similar to that after leaving the Bay, only more Cedar is to be found on this part of the route, and after twenty eight miles travel from Empire City the trail emerged from the thick forest and after travelling over sand hills for about one mile came to the place known as "Randolph City"  where a little town was built up during the gold excitement on the beach in the close vicinity in the years 1854 & 5.

24
This place at that time attracted considerable attention, but the mines soon failed and the town failed also, and at the present time there is but the frame of one building standing, the balance either burnt down, torn down or blowed down

     Randolph is situated in the sand hills about fifty feet above the level of the sea and two or three hundred yards from beach, where there are a Company of  Chinamen & a small Company of Whites at work at mining and making about two dollars per day to the hand. 
     From this place to the mouth of the  "Coquille" River a distance of about three miles you follow the Beach, with a ridge of drifting Sand hills to your left. of some two or three miles to the Coquille River which, like the Coose & Umpqua,  runs paralel [sic]  to the beach for five or six miles before it  breaks through the sand Hills to the Ocean
     About one fourth of a mile above the mouth of the River is a Ferry Boat in running order, and a house on the opposite side.   At the mouth, the River is not over one hundred yds wide at low Tide,  but wider above, being some two hundred yds wide at the Ferry 
     This River, for many years was

26
Coquille (Cokeel) is an Indian word and signifies

              Crossed the River at the Ferry + travelled over sand hills to the south about two miles, and stopped for the night at a house where there was an appearance of comfort and thrift but unfortunately for the industry here displayed, the soil of the place was of an inferior quality--, and  required much work, to produce little. Attached to the house was a beautiful flower Garden. Where flowers of all kinds seemed to flourish regardless of the inferiority of the soil
           July 16-   Got under way right early, and made out to the beach, some two or three hundred yds and continued along as near the water as possible in order to take all the advantage of the Tide washed sand, which is always much more solid than when it is deposited above high water mark passing several mining companies that appear to be making pretty good wages, finally at 12 miles came to  where the mouth of "New River" is supposed to be, which at this time is completely barred up
                "New River" is the County line between "Coose" + "Curry" Counties, and

25
noted for its numerous bands of fierce and warlike Tribes, that inhabited it, and the adjoining coast;  The most barbarous attack ever made on this River, was made on the 14th of Sept 1851, about three miles from the mouth,    At that place a party of ten half starved white men,  that had been nearly a month in the mountains were attacked and five of the party barbarously massacred, while the five survivors escaped very miraculously, the  writer of this, being the most unfortunate survivor, receiving arrow wounds in the conflict from which he did not recover for seven and one half years, 
drawing of map: pacific ocean, sand hills, coquille river, timber, point of timber, marsh, massacre of 

After this Massacre there was but little attempt to explore and settle the valley until 1853, when this and the Goose Bay Country began to attract attention and at the present time contains a population of perhaps two hundred

28
amount of good farming land, Sixes R. derives its name from a noted Indian Chief who held full sway here at an early time when the Coast was first beginning to attract attention, In 1851, at the first settlement of Port Orford, the name of the Six was given to this Chief by the whites, that word signifying friend in the Jargon language, a language or dialect spoken by nearly all the Indians and whites from the Russian possessions to Mexico, This noted chief appeared to possess unlimited power, and influence over all the surrounding tribes but (like many others of his race) mysteriously disappeared sometime during the winter of 1851 & 1852

   After passing Sixes River about ½ mile, the trail leads up the bluff again to the left, passing over the point known as "Cape Blanco" known to all Geographers & Navigators as the most western point of the United States  this point was visible from the Sand hills North of the Coquille from which place it had the appearance of a low point extending out seaward, with a higher elevation at the point covered with green timber, fir & spruce pine
    Passing the Cape, the trail keeps through barren spruce pine land common to a sandy soil, for about 4

27
is a small stream, made somewhat larger by "Flores Creek" which unites with it near its mouth forming  a "Lagoon" or Lake of about three miles in length and one in width

     This Lake is enlarged at the present time by the mouth of the River being barred up, but it is never shut up very long at one time, for the accumulating waters above soon forces a passage through the sand to the Ocean,  Upon these streams there is some valley land, and also some settlements, "Flores Creek" derives its name from Fred Flora, a young man from Oregon whose acquaintance I had the honor to make at Port Oxford in 1851
     Passing these Streams you enter Curry County and after following the beach a short distance, the route seemed to be obstructed by Rocks &c and percieving [sic] a trail leading up the bluffs to the left which led to the southward, paralel [sic] with the Coast over a level barren looking country . sandy soil, scattering spruce - pine timber when at a distance of about five miles, the trail led down a gradual descent of about ¼ mile to Sixes River a Stream of about 100 yds in width, the trail led down to its mouth about ¼ mile where I forded over to the south side, at this place it is not over ten yds wide and nearly barred up, there are few settlers on this River and a limited

30
Settlements where they safely arrived after undergoing the fatigue & suffering incident to a gauntlet through a hostile Indian Country,  About one month after the place was abandoned by the first ten pioneers the proprietors of the place organized a company of seventy men in San Francisco and sent them, well armed and equipped to locate and commence a settlement at that place, and of this number, the writer of this was included

  We landed at the Roadstead of Port Orford on the 14th of July off from the steamer "Sea Gull" having had a boisterous passage of six days from San Francisco
   Our numbers seemed to intimidate the Indians, and it was only small parties, like that of the Coquille that were attacked;  the object of locating a place at Port Orford, was to open a pack trail from that point to the mining Country in southern Oregon and northern California, and thus connect that extensive mining region with navigation, and furnish the demands of said mining country from this point,  And it was in search of a practicable route for the location of said road that the Company were engaged when overpowered by the Indians near the mouth of the Coquille,  the people of this place have failed to ever open a

29
miles when you reach "Elk river," a Stream about 30 yds wide,  Noticed a great change in this River since 1851, The Sand continually beating into its mouth has had a tendency to all the time turn the water more to the Northward, and at the present time its mouth is nearly one mile to the North from where it entered the Ocean in 1851 leaving a narrow ridge of sand between the River and Ocean

    From this stream the Trail follows over a low ridge of soft sand for one half mile with the Ocean on your right [crossed out: left] and the creek or River on your left, when you ascend the Bluffs of sand hills with scattering timber and a heavy forest some two or three hundred yds to your left, and continue for two miles to another Lagoon which lies within  about ¼ of a mile from the beach, and is of nearly one mile in  length & ½ in width,    From this Lagoon, you pass over a high promontory or head land extending into the sea, and descend on the opposite side to "Port Orford".   This place was settled in the Year 1851 and was the first place settled between "Trinidad" & the Umpqua Rivr,  The first settlement was attempted in June of that Year. by a party of ten men, who were besieged by the Indians for nearly two weeks, who were kept at a respectable distance by the Rifles of the besieged . who at last concluded to abandon the place and make the best of it by fleeing North to the Umpqua

32
of the Coquille Massacre, he afterwards located in Marin County California, and was killed by a shot from a pistol that was supposed to be unloaded in 1858

   The trail follows up this Creek in order to get around a high Mountain standing immediately on the south side of the mouth of it and which rises abruptly from the waters edge some 2000 feet in height,  This is Called "Humbug Mountain" from the first party being sent out to view a Road from Port Orford to the interior Rogue River valley, who were directed by the Town Proprietor to ascend this Mountain & from its summit they would find a straight and beautiful dividing ridge leading off easterly to the Mining Country of Southern Oregon.  The summit was reached (This humble individual being one of that party) and it proved to be a bald Mountain of round Conical form, and almost inaccessable on all sides, the theory of a Road from thence was pronounced a humbug, and hence the name of Humbug Mountain
   After striking Brush Creek the trail follows up stream crossing it some sixteen or seventeen times, and finally you find yourself near its source on the South side of the Mountain and within about one fourth mile of the beach 
   After passing this Mountain for the most of the way to Rogue River kept

31
Road to the mining Country referred to, consequently the place has never attained the importance that it would had such a route been found practicable

    In 1853 & 54 There was some little excitement here occasioned by gold being found in considerable quantities on the beach near by, and that together with a few rich deposits found on Sixes River caused the place to flourish for some little time and it was increased to about thirty buildings. but at the present time there are not over five or six 

Ocupied [sic] this place is located some forty or fifty feet above the sea, with a thick heavy forest of Fir Hemlock & Cedar back of it, and a narrow beach of sand at the foot of the bluffs in front of it,  Altogether it is pleasantly situated, but exposed to all South & south West winds, the harbor is a poor one, only sheltered from the North & East 
July 17th

      Started from Port Orford for Rogue River, the trail follows the beach for 1½ miles and then bears off to the left over high hills and deep gulches for about five or six miles when you descend by a steep tortuous route to the narrow timbered bottoms of "Brushes Creek" about 1 ½ miles from its mouth,  This is a small Creek and derives its name from Gilbert Brush one of my old Comrads [sic] from San Francisco in 1851 and also one of the survivors

34
Engines and all sorts of machinery destroyed

  But that Indian war of 1855&6 finished the "poor Indians," for all the survivors were removed to the Reservation upon the Siletz some fifty miles North of the Umpqua
  The town at the mouth of the River has been rebuilt, stands on the south side, is called Ellensburg and is the County seat of Curry County.  Mining operations have been resumed and business is quite flourishing.   a narrow Strip of bottom land on each side of the River, with occasional little patches in diferent [sic] places constitutes the farming land from which the place is to be supplied, an extensive range or ranges of Bald hills on either side [crossed out:  of the]  yields an abundance of grass and they are already ocupied [sic] by numerous bands of Cattle which occupies [crossed out: the] a good portion of the time of about one fourth of the Citizens, and about one fourth is engaged in mining and trading and the balance in fishing and other business such as dairymen, laborers, dead heads &c

33
back a short distance from the beach, over hills and across deep ravines for the abrupt rocky Cliffs and headlands rendered it impossible to follow the beach much of the way, you occasionly [sic] pass a deserted  house and more frequently the ruins of buildings burned by Indians during the Indian war of 1855-56 and now and then approach the beach until you reach the Mouth of Rogue River, where I arrived in the evening, a distance of 30 miles from Port Orford,  About two miles before you reach Rogue River you pass the old Fortification where all the whites of this vicinity were gathered together during the Indian war of 1855&6.  The fort is built of turf to the height of about six feet, and situated on a level tract of open Country, some two or three hundred yds from the beach with a range of Bald hills some 4 or 500 yds back from

   In this rude fortification about 100 whites, men, women &  children were collected for some two months, and for much of this time were closely besieged.  The Indians were more savage, and done more damage to life and property in this locality than in any other part of the Country
    Some 30 or 40 persons were killed in this immediate vicinity and all the buildings including a flourishing little town at the mouth of the River was burned and mining property in the shape of flumes

36 
fatal to the whole party, they deemed it prudent to abandon their rockbound Fortress and make their way to the settlements on the Umpqua River

    From Port Orford to Rogue River the Coast is broken and Craggy.  high conical rocks may be seen at nearly every point and headland, rising to the height of one or two hundred feet, and often as far out to sea as the eye can reach rocks may be seen, thus making this part of the Coast dangerous to navigators who are not well posted as to their localities
July 23d
   Left Port Orford for Umpqua via the Mountain Trail to the upper part of the Umpqua Valley, The trail leads directly back from the Coast, into heavy timbered land, nearly level and at three miles passed a Steam Saw Mill in successful operation, and at six miles made short descent to Elk River which is about twenty yds wide, with a small bottom of prarie land, claimed and under cultivation
  About two miles from Elk River you arrive at and cross Sixes River which is about as large as Elk.  The trail thus far is a good one, heavy timbered country, fir hemlock and some of the prettyest Cedar groves to be found any where upon this coast
  From Sixes the trail leads up the mountain and continues in a very rough and tortuous route, over fallen timber, ravines & rocky

35
a rapid that obstructs all further navigation

    Around about the immediate vicinity of the mouth of the River, there are, in all perhaps twenty five occupied buildings, the place appears to be improving, but I can discern no cause why it should.  for there appears to be no natural resource of the place whatever

July 19th

    Left Rouge River on my return, and travelled the same route to Port Orford, over a rough hilly trail, with open patches of land bordering the ocean but generally a heavy growth of timber to your right [crossed out:  left].
    In front of the Town of Port Orford is a small Promontory, extending into the sea a short distance, with nearly perpendicular walls of rock upon three sides  only accessable [sic] from the beach by a narrow foot path at an angle of nearly 45 [degree symbol]; the top of this is nearly level, covered with soil with a small growth of shrubbery and one or two moderate sized spruce pine trees
    Upon this rock the first company of (the ten pioneers previously referred to) of settlers fortified themselves, and upon this almost inaccessable rock they were besieged by the blood thirsty savages; with a four pounder, covering the trail that led upon to the rock, they were in a manner safe from an immediate attack but the prospect of a siege, that might prove

38
after following upstream, on the North side, about one or two hundred yds you enter the Prarie [sic] known as the "Enchanted Prarie", so called, from the Indians having some kind of superstition connected with it, this prarie is claimed and occupied, and at this place I stopped for the night
July 26
Left Enchanted prarie and followed up the stream for about ten miles over a rough brushy road. crossing numerous small streams, when the trail leads off to the Eastward over a high range of timbered Mts. and after nearly a day of laborious travel the trail descended very precipitately for about one and one half miles to level land and in about one half mile from the foot of the Mountains you enter Cammas Valley and which proved to be an open prarie Country, thickly settled the first settlement since Ench [sic]  Prarie    From this my course was E. across this valley which appeared to be about four or five miles in extent.  in the vicinity of this valley the S. fork of the Coquille takes its rise and at the crossing, four miles after entering the vally it is a stream of about twenty five feet in width

  After Crossing this stream the Road, which now had become a wagon Road, bears off still Easterly over a range of low hills, thinly timbered with Oak, for about six miles, then gradually descends into what is known as "ten mile prarie" where I stopped for the night;  This range of hills last mentioned is the dividing ridge between the Coquille and the Umpqua Rivers; some time before entering Cammas Valley, you cross the line from Coos into Douglas county,  It is not precisely known where the line is, has never been established

37
gulches, principally through burnt woods, and after travelling about 25 miles, passing but one house since leaving Elk river I put up at a place known as the "Calf Ranch" where there was a family living; here is a range of open prarie & Bald hills and has been occupied by herdsmen for one or two years;
July 24th

   A very cold morning, travelled about fifteen miles, over the same kind of rough mountain road occasionally passing over bald hills, where grass was good and where may be seen an almost incredible number of Elk horns, which seem to be more plenty upon these small praries, than any other place I have seen in the country.  In fact the Coast Country of Southern Oregon & Northern Cal cannot be surpassed for game, by any other locality West of the Rocky Mts.  Deer Elk & Bear is the principle [sic] 
   After fifteen miles, arrived at the South fork of Coquille where there is some good farming land, which has been occupied & cultivated for the last five or six years; At this place I stopped for the night, this Valley is narrow consisting of some prarie and some timbered bottoms, nearly all of which is claimed.  This stream is about twenty yds wide, and some distance farther up stream, gold is found in paying quantities.  some time during the day I passed from Curry to Coos County, the line is not distincly [sic] known

July 25

     Left the Valley of the south fork of the Coquille and pursued my course to the Northward, over Mountains heavily timbered but nearly all deadened by fires, with a thick undergrowth of Black Berry Briers and shrubbery common to the Country, and after 16 miles arrived at the middle {crossed out: North] fork of the Coquille a Stream of 12 yds in width which is forded at this place, and

40
"Garden Valley" which is a beautiful river bottom of about one mile in width and five or six in length forming one of the choicest localities for farming to be found in Oregon!  From this point my course was nearly N. by a track, over a hilly country for about 8 miles to the intersection of the Scottsburg & Winchester wagon Road, which road Intersected at the crossing of the Calipooiah [sic] Creek, a stream of about seventy-five feet in width, which divides the counties of Douglas & Umpqua.  the Road crosses this stream upon a good frame bridge and passes for two miles over a level tract of land & then enters a Range of Oak hills and ridges which continues for about four miles farther to the head of a Creek, tributary to the Umpqua known as the "Little Cañon Creek", the road follows down this Creek three miles to it mouth & then turns to the right and keeps the bank of the Umpqua for about 8 miles through narrow timbered bottoms the most of the way when you enter an open Country of level bottom and rolling prarie land which you pass over and at two miles after entering this open land you intersect the Umpqua again at "Crescent Ferry" in the precinct of Elkton, and after crossing, a ride of [crossed out: three] five miles brought me to my starting point again, having been absent seventeen days, and travelled three hundred and fifty miles

39
Traveled today about 35 miles, over a pretty rough Road a good portion of the way
July [crossed out: 26] 27

     Ten mile prarie derives its name from the first supposition that it was but ten miles from Roseburg, the County seat of Douglas County but is now believed to be sixteen.  It is a gently rolling Country, with frequent groves of Oak timber upon the ridges, and occasionally, Yellow Pine may be seen, in the form of large trees, standing by themselves at short intervals from each other

     Left the house of my Entertainment this morning and changed my course from E. to nearly N. and at a distance of about five miles entered upon a very handsome level prarie.  Called "Looking Glass prarie" which I should judge to be four or five miles in width and five or six in length, good rich soil, all settled and has a beautiful appearance.  This prarie is beautifully marked by lines of timber running through it, in narrow Strips.  indicating the course of the "Looking Glass Creek" and its tributary

   This Stream running through the Valley, is about ten feet wide and makes its way to the Umpqua
   
   Leaving Looking Glass prarie . my course was about N.E. over low hills and gently rolling praries, with groves of Oak, principally upon the ridges, and at fifteen miles intersected the Umpqua River where there is an established Ferry, which renders communication, between the settlements of each side of the River, as easy as can be expected in as new a Country as this.  Crossed the river at this place and found myself at the lower extremity of

42
Notes of a trip from Elkton to Walla Walla and return by L.L. Williams 1860
Feb 22

    Left the mouth of "Elk Creek" in the morning, following a trail known as the "Elk Creek trail" which leads up said Creek fifteen miles and there intersecting the great thoroughfare leading N.& S. through Oregon to California
   The trail for three miles passes through an open Country with prarie & timbered land to the first crossing of the Creek, which was pretty high fording, but got over safely, though somewhat wet, the creek being about thirty yards wide and midsides to my horses.  From this ford it is about one mile of bottom land to the 2d crossing, which was not quite as deep as the first, but more rapid 
   After crossing this ford, the track immediately ascends the highest and steepest hill upon the trail.  it is about one half mile from the creek to the summit at an angle of 30 [degree symbol]  and for three miles further the trail leads over a rough hilly country heavily timbered, and then descends from the hills to the narrow timbered bottom lands upon the Creek and after following up stream for about one mile you again ford at a place where the creek is narrower and deeper than at the other fords, but smooth sand bottom which renders it safer than the other fords that are not as deep & more rocky
   Three or four miles further the trail leads out of the timbered bottoms and enters country more open, with praries and timbered ridges alternating
