44
of small shrubbery    As you reach the foot of the Mountain on the N. side, you are upon a small stream of some two feet in width, which is the main branch of the "Siuslaw" River, a stream that takes its rise near here, and runs westerly through the Coast Range of Mts and empties into the Ocean twenty five miles N. of the mouth of the Umpqua

   Passing the Siuslaw one quarter mile, I stopped for dinner at the house of D.B. Cartwright, a place of Entertainment, which has the appearance of as much pleasure and comfort as any place yet seen !  A large and elegantly furnished house capable of accommodating scores of travellers  [sic] always well and luxuriantly supplied with the necessaries of life, [five lines completely marked out]
  Leaving this place, I proceeded about six miles through a thick settled Country and stopped for the night where I had as good accommodations as one could well expect, in a small house with a family of at least a dozen children of all sizes, sexes and conditions
   Soon after leaving Cartwrights, you enter upon the waters of "Long Tom" a tributary of the Willamette which drains a large portion of this part of the Country, forming innumerable sloughs and marshes which during the winter season is almost impassible from the amount of mud and water

Feb 24    Set out in the morning

43
[pencilled in top margin}
Youncalla (Yank(Eagle); Culla (bird)  Indian
[ink text continues]
with occasionally a settler, until you intersect the Road referred to, which leads from Oregon to California; near the intersection of this road the Creek forks, the more Eastern fork, heads off to the Eastward and runs through the flourishing Vally of Youcalla, and bears the name of Elk Creek while the more northern branch is called "Pass Creek" and takes its rise in the Calipooia Mts and runs a S. course and forms a junction at this place.   Youcalla is an Indian word and the name was given to the highest Bald Mountain in the vicinity by the Aboriginees [sic] of the Country

       Youcalla is the handsomest part of Umpqua County, was the first settled and contains some of the most wealthy men in the County

Feb 23d

   Left Youcalla, and pursued my way to the N. crossing Elk & Pass Creeks near their junction and kept up Pass Creek on the left side for about six miles passing several localities of farmers and one Saw Mill that seemed to be doing a good business, when I arrived at Estes's a a[sic] house of Entertainment and within one half mile of the foot of the Calipooiah mountain
   The Calipooia mountain is a cross Spur or range connecting the Cascades on the East with the Coast Range of Mts on the west, it is merely a timbered ridge, eight miles from one base to the other, of gradual ascent & descent, a good wagon Road over it, is the county line between Umpqua & Lane Counties
   It is timbered principally with fir, and cedar peculiar to the highlands, and a thick growth

46

   Stayed at this place until March 9th when the weather appearing favorable, I set out to attempt the passage of the Cascade Mts by the pass by the middle fork of the Willamette
   Arrived at Eugene City, as distance of eight miles through a level prarie country thickly settled, which at this time of the year is considerably cut up with swales ponds &c causing it to be pretty wet under foot and pretty muddy in general,  Geese and Ducks of all kinds. sizes and colors. may be seen upon these praries during the winter season, Millions of geese are sometimes to be seen in one flock, generally the white geese are to be seen in the greatest number and in the spring they disappear to the Northward to return again as winter approaches
    Oregon may be properly divided into four divisions, the Willamette Valley the Umpqua Valley, Rogue River Valley & the Walla Walla Country which includes the Country E. of the Cascade Mts.
   The Willamette River River [sic] takes its rise in the Cascade Mts some 80 miles S.E. from this place, runs N.W. to the vicinity of Eugene City then turns N. and at a distance of about 130 miles empties into the "Columbia" River
   The River is formed by the united waters of three considerable streams, the most southern of which is called the "Coast Fork" a stream of fifty yds wide, that rises in the Calipooia Mts. and runs nearly N. and forms a junction with the "Middle Fork" (which is considered the main Willamette) about three miles above Eugene City

45
and travelled about 14 miles over a gently rolling country timbered & prarie, Settled all the way, very much cut up with swales & sloughs, some of which were crossed by Corduroy roads, or log bridges, others that were belly deep to my horses, and filled with almost incredible numbers of wild Ducks, when I arrived at a ridge of dry land known in this part of the Valley as the "Fern Ridge" from the abundance of small Fern growing upon it, here I stopped with an acquaintance who is engaged in farming, has a very pleasant locality; a few [?rods?] E. of his house you have a fine view of the country, for many miles in every direction, to the S.E. eight miles distant lies "Eugene City" one of the most flourishing towns in Oregon, but the principle part of the City is obscured by a point of timber running up from the Willamette River.  From there the course of the River can be traced for twenty miles to the Northward, by the thick growth of timber upon its banks;  To the W. & N.W. you have a swale of the width of about one mile, covered with water during the winter season, and through which the"Long Tom" and "Coyote" (a tributary to Long Tom) passes, and form a junction a short distance below, bordering these two streams is a dense undergrowth of Ash willow Crab Apple &c alternated with open spaces of Marsh land that produces an abundance of grass and forms splendid localities for Geese & Ducks, in which this Country abounds

   To the W. of these Creeks you have the heavily timbered Coast Range of Mts, many of the highest peaks at this time covered with snow

48
[tim-]bered, thickly settled country, to the mouth of the Coast Fork, and here I was misdirected, up the Coast fork instead of the middle fork, and was not aware of the mistake until I had travelled about fifteen miles up the coast fork, all the way through a beautiful vally [sic] thickly settled.

  Here I was again put on the right track & directed on a Road that run angling through the Country and intersects the middle fork road some fifteen miles from Eugene city 
  Immediately after I [crossed out: was] turned upon the right direction [crossed  out: road] again I came to the Coast Fork Ferry, and crossed over the stream being about fifty yds wide, some three miles from the Ferry, through timber and prarie land and you enter a pretty little place called "Cloverdale" which is situated on a low and level tract of land and contains about 12 buildings    From this place my course was E. over gently rolling timbered & prarie land, very muddy & somewhat cut up with sloughs, when I intersected the Middle fork Road, and continued for five miles further and stopped for the night having travelled about thirty miles and was only fifteen from Eugene city my starting point this morning

March 11

     Set out in the morning and travelled three miles through level timbered land to the first ford on the Willamette (or middle fork) where the stream is about 100 yds wide & was midsides to my horses, a short distance farther and I found myself in an open prarie

47

  (The Middle Fork before referred to as Willamette  While the North fork or "McKenzie Fork" as it is more familiarly known rises in the Cascade Mts runs N. and enters the Willamette some three or four miles below Eugene City.  Willamette is a contraction of the Indian word "Wah lam mut" given by the natives to the "Oregon City" falls some fifteen miles from the mouth of the River
    Eugene City contains about 150 buildings and a good portion of them are occupied by families who have moved into the place for the purpose of schooling their children.   Derives its name from the Town proprietor Eugene Skinner, who first laid off a town here, and who at the present time owns a good portion of the real Estate in the immediate vicinity    It is situated about two hundred yds from the left bank of the Willamette, on a handsome level tract of land, interspressed [sic] with scattering Oak trees, open to the main valley to the Westward, and narrow Valley up the River S. Easterly, while to the south some two or three miles distant lies a range of timbered hills, the most prominent amongst them is "Spencers Butte" a round conical shaped peak rising a little above the surrounding hills, while a few rods to the N. is "Skinners Butte" a Bald hill of moderate height, and beyond that the timbered flats of the Willamette River

March 10th

    Left Eugene for the Cascade Mts via the middle fork.  followed up the River about three miles over a gently rolling, thickly tim-

50
about 50 yds wide, with a gravel ridge about two thirds the way across, which extends up stream about 200 yds, could see no place where the Road left the River on the opposite bank, Whereupon I made for the gravelly Island, I found the water deeper than the other fords below, it was so deep and rapid that I came near being swept down stream, it was with dificulty [sic} that I could keep my place in the saddle, finally landed on the lower extremity of the gravel bed, and upon this I rode up and down for some time before I could discover any place where the Road left it, or any place where my horses could land if I should swim them, at last from the extreme upper end of the bar, I saw a place some little distance upstream that had the appearance of the Road, I crossed to the shore by angling upstream about 30 yds this channel was belly deep and very rapid

   From this crossing the road is over rough and uneven ground for five miles when you come to a Rapid Creek of 10 ft in width rushing down out of the Mts with its bottom covered with large round boulders, over which a violent current is rushing, thus forming a bad crossing for horses, one quarter mile from this, the trail leads over a point called "Point Lookout" where the mountain terminates very abruptly in a perpendicular height of 100 feet, an accumulated mass of loose rock &c has been deposited at the foot of the Cliff extending to the Rivers edge, which is but few feet from it, and this accumulated mass of a few feet lies in an angle of 45º and over this the trail has been made

49
in the midst of a pretty settlement with the timbered bottoms bordering the River to my right and "Butte Disappointment to my left, this is a Butte about 1000 feet high, bald on the south side and heavy timber on the North, the summit being the divide between the prarie & timber, the southern base of the Butte is occupied by settlers and is the extreme of civilization upon the middle fork

  Leaving the prarie around this Butte, you follow upstream upon bottoms principally, heavily timbered for six miles. and then the trail bears off to the left over high timbered land for about four miles and then descends to the River again, where there is an open tract of thinly timbered land, with pretty good grass, and as the day was somewhat advanced I thought best to camp here for the night
   Saw sign of deer to day, but no game of any kind appeared in sight, although there appeared to be considerable beaver sign along the River

Monday March 12th

    A fine Morning, started early & in ¼ mile came to the second crossing of the River which I found to be about 60 yds wide, rapid and almost swimming my animals, landed upon the opposite side and proceeded up stream and at a short distance crossed another channel of about 50 yds wide which forms an Island of perhaps one mile in length, following up River on heavy and thickly timbered bottoms, upon which may be seen a goodly quantity of Cottonwood, crossing sloughs that were full of water, and noticing any amount of "Beaver Cuttings, when you arrive at the third crossing of the river, which appeared to be

52 
but not much of it that is adapted to cultivation.

  The soil is gravelly and rocky near the river, and back near the foot of the hills it is a light red or second rate soil
  This locality is fifty miles from Eugene City and here I stopped a day or two, for the purpose of obtaining a little better supply of provisions, to last until I could reach the settlements on the Deschutes River, about 250 miles distant, I engaged sufficient for ten days, but recieved [sic] a scant supply for three, but with a good rifle, and a country abounding in game, I was not alarmed at the prospect of travelling one or two hundred miles, with no other provisions than could be supplied by the use of the Rifle

Thursday March 15th

    Set out, and at two miles left the prarie country, and turned more to the right, following the course of the River, crossing a pretty and rapid stream some fifty or sixty feet in width and a short distance farther another stream of nearly the same width, rapidly hurrying its way on to join the Willamette ¼ mile to your right about two miles from this last stream, pass through a handsome prarie of about forty acres at which place is located a small band of Klamath Indians, who subsist principly [sic] by hunting.  One half mile from this prarie you cross a creek of 20 feet in width, with a violent current rushing over large boulders, rendering the crossing dificult [sic].  One mile from this and arrive at the eighth crossing of the Willamette

51

   It is a dangerous point, scarcely passible, some places animals are obliged to step up and down rocks of two feet in height, and if a slip or fall should occur, they would in all probability be precipitated into the River below some twenty or thirty feet, the distance over the point is about seventy five yds, when you are on River bottoms again, passing the point about 100 yds and again cross the River which is about 75 yds wide and misdsides to my animals, nearly all the way across, landing safely upon the left bank and continue up river, a short distance to the fifth crossing which is about fifty yds wide, rapid, but not deep, and in one half mile cross back to the opposite side again where I found the water deep & rapid, nearly running over the horses back, a short distance up stream and you cross a channel of the river of same width onto an Island of rocks and sand, covered with a sparse growth of willow and Cottonwood, at the extreme upper point of this Island, the road again crosses the River, and found it to be as deep as any ford crossed to day.  A distance of about three miles from this ford and the Road enters an opening of prarie country, and here I found there were several bands of Cattle amounting to some 300 head, that were being ranched at this place, and two or three Log Cabins occupied by those employed in ranching.  this open country consists of some five or six sections of prarie land, principally hills or high Tablelands, somewhat cut up with little valleys and ravines
   It is good range for a limited number of stock

54

   This ford is not deep, crossed the main Channel and camped on an Island and tied my horses to trees without grass; the Indians had left me at the last ford, in a Cold, tired and hungry condition begging pitifully for something to eat, but I only laughed at their foolishness

Friday 16th

    Started early and in a few minutes crossed two narrow channels of the River on to the main land, and at about two miles crossed the fifteenth ford which was of about the same width and depth of the others 
   At three miles from this you cross a rapid stream of 10 ft in width and then enter upon rolling land thinly timbered with yellow Pine, with not much undergrowth but a fine quality of Bunch grass which I was glad to discover, for my horses had had no grass since the morning of Yesterday,  As you enter these prarie woods, known as the "Pine Openings" you leave the river to your right and do not approach it again;  opposite the pine woods across the river, the Mts rise to a considerable elevation and one or two of them terminating at their tops in sharply conical, rocky peaks, some resembling the steeples of a church.   After my horses had had sufficient time to graze, I started on, and soon after leaving the pine woods, and entering a comparatively level tract of heavy timbered land, consisting of very large and tall timber.  Fir, cedar, but principly hemlock.  about 1½ miles after entering this heavy timber crossed a stream of thirty feet in width, after which I perceived the face of the country to be gradually ascending, which ascent

53
which is fifty yds wide, not deep or dificult [sic] to ford, here I was overtaken by four Indians, who were going up river to visit some of their dusky companions somewhere up in the Mts, they were on foot, and wading the river at this season of the year, which is deep and cold, seemed to be their delight, before starting in they procured a stick of perhaps six feet in length, and all grasping a firm hold of it, side by side, they boldly marched into the water, walked slowly, over the smoth [sic] slippery rocks, clinging to the stick as if life depended upon it, and if one slipped or lost his footing the others braced themselves for his support until he gained a foothold, the largest and strongest Indian always taking the place farthest upstream, to receive the strongest force of the current.    A few minutes ride brought me to the ninth ford, of 40 yds wide, deep and rapid.  was obliged to follow up stream in the water, on the opposite side about 150 yds and again crossed back, the two crossings are made to avoid a point of rocks making down from the Mts to the river

    Not far from these two crossings I arrived at the Eleventh ford, 50 yds wide, and nearly swimming my horses, the Indians were swept down stream some distance, but landed safely, Shortly reached the twelfth ford, 50 yds wide and as deep as any crossed today =     The thirteenth ford, at which I arrived in a few minutes, fifty yds wide, and crossed by angling down stream, landing some fifty yds farther down than you enter, an half hours ride from here and cross a rapid stream of 12 feet in width, and at  dark arrived at the 14 ford which is perhaps five miles from the last

56

   The land from the Settlements at Butte Disappointment to the height of land attained, is of a similar character.  It is timbered all the way with fir Cedar, pine, and hemlock, while the river bottoms which are generally about one fourth of mile in width are timbered with Cottonwood, Alder, Ash Willow, vine - Maple &c. the soil on the river bottoms is of little depth, heavy deposit of loose boulders immediately underlying it, and in many places, and in fact a good part of the distance, the soil (if any) is underlying the boulders, which are promiscuously scattered all through the bottoms, which apparently at some time have formed the bottom of the River
  Nearly all the formations yet seen are of a Volcanic or Basaltic nature, except specimens of quartz found in the bed of the river
     One item of interest, that would be observed by the curious minded, is the numerous piles of rock that are to be seen at nearly every rocky point or ravine or rocky stream, piled in a round conical form, by the Indians, I have vainly endeavoured to ascertain the cause of this, but thus far have met with no success,   Some Indians gave me to understand that they were to represent so many weddings, and others so many deaths, by others to represent cases of sickness and by others that they were acts of the squaws during their monthly periods,  From the above reasons a person cannot arrive at any conclusion, but it is evident that there is some kind of superstition connected with it
    Indian Ranches, old and new and unoccupied are to be seen at short intervals along

55
continued for about 12 miles to the foot of a steep mountain so completely buried up in snow, as to almost discourage any attempt to force a passage over it.  The snow began to appear in "patches" some five or six miles back and for the last three miles has entirely covered the ground, at the foot of this mountain which I will describe as the summit mountain, the snow was about two feet deep!  I made the attempt and succeeded in getting my two animals about half way to the top, but the snow becoming deeper at every step, I was obliged to abandon the idea of getting them over.  I consequently retraced my steps to the foot of the Mountain, and left my animals and made the ascent on foot, and found the snow at the top to be about five feet deep.  once on the summit of this elevation found it to be a ridge leading off to the Eastward, with spurs, Cañons &c making off from it at short intervals.  I followed this ridge upon which I found traces of the road above the snow, for about three miles.  The Clouds running low I could not get a view any distance in an easterly direction, but as far as I could see the prospect looked gloomy, the snow increased in depth and I readily came to the conclusion that it was an impossibility to cross over to the Des Chutes Valley with horse at the present time.  Thereupon I determined to retrace my steps to the herdsmens Ranches, and there await the disappearance of the snow,  I camped in the Snow at the first water course about two miles back from the foot of the Mountain, and was again obliged to tie up my horses without grass

  The farthest point reached was about one hundred miles from Eugene City, and was near the summit of the Cascade Mts dividing the waters of the Willamette River on the West and those of the Des Chutes River on the East

58
accident occurred as the Emigrants were crossing in the year 1855.  A Wagon was upset as it was drove into the River and a Mrs. Petty a lady Emigrant was thrown with violence into the River and from the bruises and strangulation soon expired, her grave is said to be on the left hand of the river, near this ford.  I did not discover it.  Crossed the second ford and after travelling about 25 miles camped for the night.  The weather was showery towards evening, and to secure myself from the wet, I took possession of a pretty neat looking Indian Ranch, one side of it afforded me fine shelter, and the other an excellent supply of fire wood 

    These ranches a [sic] built wholly of dry fir bark. peeled from logs and dead trees, and lain over a frame work of small poles, in such a manner as to be a protection from rain,   There being little grass here in places I turned my horses out in order to secure as much as possible.   It being scattered so that it would be out of the reach of picket ropes altogether

Sund. 18th     Sunday

    My horses were missing, and the first idea was that the Indians had stolen them, but soon found their tracks leading down River, apparently grazing along as little patches of grass appeared 
    Followed the trail to the next ford below, and found that they had crossed, the water was deep cold and rapid,  I did not like to wade it, but there was no other alternative,  It was a cold bath to my lower extremities, but reached the shore and soon overtook my horses, who had found a little grass plot and was quietly grazing, returned for my saddle, Blankets &c and soon got under way and reached the Stock

57
River bottoms, built for hunting Camps, for it is evident from what I have seen that the Indians are of a roving disposition

     There is not much game to be seen along the river, but by the "sign" and the large numbers of deers horns to be seen around the old ranches, it is evident that it is abundant in the Mts
    There is no evidence of Elk until you arrive at the thickly timbered country above the pine woods there I saw plenty of tracks, and more particularly in the edge of the snow, where they appeared quite abundant, also the tracks of the large gray wolf was plenty, and near the termination of the trip saw the foot marks of the large hare or rabbit, know in this country as the "Jackass Rabbit", an animal that I have never seen west of the Cascade Mts. in the Willamette or Umpqua Valleys
    This Route across the Mts was opened in 1853&4 for the purpose of attracting the Emigration to the middle and southern portions of Oregon, and during those years there was a good portion of the Emigrants come in by this route, which is somewhat nearer than the northern route, or "Old Emigrant Road".  Old wrecks of wagons, broken Ox yokes, old Stoves &c may be seen upon the whole length of the road, while the Skeleton remains of dead Cattle may be seen at short intervals

Saturday March 17

    Very cold last night and froze solid, the wolves howled tremendously, frightening my horses so as to cause them to break loose once during the night     Started early and by 10 A.M. arrived at the pine woods and again stopped to give my horses a chance to graze.    Saddling up I reached the upper ford and crossed safely.   At this place a melancholy

60

   The Cascades seem to be a solid range of Mountains of Snow, will require much warm weather to open the road over them      During my rambles to day killed a deer and saw several more, Carried the choicest parts to camp where I arrived about noon, and found several Indians there lying round in the snow,  The sight and smell of Venison seemed to enliven them very much, and they started off upon my track in order to secure the remainder of the deer, and after a short space of time returned with the head legs and intestines, but by far the most interesting part was two half grown fawns that they had taken from the intestines, and seemed to value them more highly than all the rest, they were preparing to make a feast from them.  No doubt they were "young & tender"

Sat Apr 14th

    Fair weather, but an unfortunate day for me, was thrown from a horse dislocating my shoulder and breaking my colarbone [sic], I was hurt severely, and considerably stunned by the fall, but soon got straightened up, and discovered that it was necessary to have Surgical assistance as soon as possible,  Whereupon I ordered a gentle horse saddled and started for Eugene City fifty miles distant, arrived at the first ford below, and unfortunately the water was to [sic] high for fording, this placed me in an awkward fix, but was soon convinced of the only way to act, that was to return to the ranch, and stop until morning (as the day was somewhat advanced) and then go down an Indian trail that goes down on the N. side of the River all the way to the settlements without crossing.   I found before I reached the Ranch, that I

59
Ranch in the afternoon, and turned out my horses to await the disapearance [sic] of the snow in the Mts
Sunday March 25th

    Fine day, made a trip over nearly all the open land in the vicinity, found it to be a hilly, but good grass country, and as much stock upon it as it will safely support,    From some of the moderate elevations I had a fine view of the mountains towards the head of the river, which is a S.E. course from here.   "Diamond Peak" a mountain of perpetual Snow, looms up above any of the surrounding Mts.  it is not a conical peak but more in the form of a ridge of moderate length running N. & S.  It is situated in the Eastern part of the Cascade Mts and near the head waters of the Willamette and Des Chutes River, estimated at 40 miles from this place
     Saw today around the margin of the prarie, numerous contrivances for the entrapping of Wolves, built in the form and fashion of a small rude log Cabin, with a small trap door which is spring as the animal enters, the larger ones appear more comfortable and probably would make better dwelling than the rude bark shanties of the Indians
     Also saw where the Indians had made sad havoc upon the bark of the young and thrifty alders probably used for food during some starvation season which often overtakes them

Wed Apr 11th
     For the last week it has been showery with Snow squalls nearly every day, today is warm & pleasant, went out on to the high lands to obtain an up river view, it appeared gloomy and dismal

62
winding around on the sides of others, climbing over fallen timber, and huge piles of rocks, and through thickets of brush, which, under most common circumstances would be pronounced almost impassible and at 11 A.M. Entered the Emigrant Road at the ford at Point Lookout;  It was pleasant & warm by this time, the snow off from the bushes, but I had become thoroughly wet in the morning so much so that I was somewhat alarmed fearing I might take cold, and thus cause my injury to become {crossed out:  more] much worse than it would otherwise be, for by this time it had become so sore that it was difficult for me to walk over one fourth of a mile without resting myself

    From Point Lookout, I follow the Road to the next ford, about four or five miles and then follow the Indian trail again down the right bank of the River, over rough Mts and across deep gulches, the route much obstructed by fallen timber, which was a serious obstruction to overcome
   After some three hours travel of considerable pain and suffering from the many slips and falls that must necessarily occur in travelling over such a trail I arrived at the first crossing above the settlements and near the place of my encampment of March 11th
   The day being somewhat advanced, and my arm and shoulder being severely painful, I set down and held a consultation with myself whether to camp for the night or go on to the settlements 10 miles distant, I did not wish to camp out if I could help it, and at the same time did not think it possible to reach the settlement for

61
was not likely to be able to ride, for every step of the horse was a sudden jar that could not be avoided, and particularly going up and down any hill or gently inclined plain, I felt this jarring and shaking more sensibly
Sund. 15th

     Spent an uncomfortable night without much of any sleep, this morning my arm and shoulder were painful, and somewhat swelled
     It was snowing furiously, and the ground and bushes were white with snow, rendering the trip a gloomy one to contemplate, but it could not be delayed, I was too sore to ride, started out on foot, accompanied by one of the herdsmen to assist in crossing a stream called the "North Fork" about five miles distant, to reach this stream the Indian trail leads over a high Mountain, with a steep and rocky descent, with the N. Fork at the foot of it, where we arrived in good time
    My shoulder paining me very much, and as if to add to misery, the bushes through which the trail passes is covered with snow, thus causing the travelling to be very disagreeable.  Arrive at N. Fork and rode across upon the horse, and from the opposite side turned the horse loose and started him back to my Comrade who will return with him to the Camp
    The N. Fork is a stream of beautifully clear cold water, swift current, belly deep to  horse and about fifty yds wide, the storm has cleared off and the sun has made its appearance, with the prospect of a warm day, I set out alone for the settlements, the trail was a poor one, not easily followed, it kept along the River where there were bottoms to admit of it, and again off from the River, over high Mountains and

64 
upstream and strained every nerve and muscle to keep it steady, and a sufficient headway on to prevent its sinking before I reached the shore

    With the use of but one arm, I found that sculling had a painful effect upon the other, for with the poor facilities at my command, it was impossible to propel the Craft across the stream without shaking, twisting and jarring my other shoulder to such an extent that, after I had effected a landing I was obliged to lie down on the bank unable to travel for some little time
    I had, to day, concluded to consult Dr Fisher, at whose house I put up on the night of March 10th on my way up river, whose surgical skill is well spoken of;  I landed from the leaky skiff two thirds full of water about one mile from his residence, at which place I made my way as soon as I felt able.   The Dr was absent to Eugene City, was expected home at night, but did not come

Tuesday Apr 17th

    The Dr would surely be home today so I concluded that the best thing to be done was to keep quiet and await his return.  shoulder was very sore, but not very painful when quiet, seem to swell as the day advanced.  The Dr did not arrive today

Wed 18th

    Concluded to start for Eugene although suffering some little, the road was dry and day pleasant, travelled for [?7?] 1/2 miles through a level prarie country, interspersed with lines of timber, and dotted all over with beautiful

63
I was obliged to support myself with a stick while walking to avoid the jar that must necessarily follow each step as much as possible.  I finally concluded to keep on and if I failed to reach civilization, to make the best of it under a tree, but fortunately I succeeded in reaching the nearest house a little after dark, where I was cared for as well as circumstances would permit

      The route thus far seemed very much more animated than when I passed over it one month ago at that time I saw no game, nor much indication of any while now ducks were seen in the river and sloughs patridges [sic] or pheasants were drumming in the thickets grouse were hooting in the tall evergreens, quails were often frightened out of the road from before me, and deer were often seen jumping across the road or grazing about the margin of the river or sloughs
      Spent an uncomfortable night and started pretty early for Eugene City, was obliged to travel down river some four miles in order to get over to the opposite side, there was a skiff, but no man at home in the neighborhood to see me over, but the lady of the house sympathized with me, and gave me liberty to use the skiff if I was able to cross with it.  I found it to be an old leaky craft not fit or safe for any one to cross in, it was full of water, but I hauled it up and bailed the water out; and then rigged one of the paddles upon the stern to answer the purpose of sculling oar, and shoved it off, the River was rapid and seventy five yds wide & the skiff leaking badly, I feared I could not make a landing on the opposite side, but trusted to providence and my own right arm, and headed the skiff quartering

66
by pulling directly in front and the Drs foot was also placed to the front part of the shoulder, to place the collar bone in its proper place, and in this position I was held firmly with the united force of three or for [sic] men pulling and tugging at my arm, for several moments, which was surely painful to me.  until the bones were heard to grind together as they slipped into their proper place    It was a painful operation, I thought it almost impossible to endure it, and was rejoiced when it was over, my arm was bound up and tied to keep it in its proper place and I was put to bed in the Drs Office with orders to not leave for a day or two, but soon becoming comfortable, I found myself able to get up & was allowed to go about wherever I wished
Wed May 7th

     My shoulder has improved slowly since it was set, I have been under the Drs care ever since but now as I am getting the use of it a little, and not likely to require any more surgical assistance I obtained leave of absence, and having business back to the place of my misfortune, I set out and stopped for the night at Whitmores, on the Coast fork

Thurs May 8th

    Arrived at Dr Fishers and stopped for the day

Frid May 9th

     Started up river and was obliged to camp out below Point Look out, it commenced raining in the evening and I availed myself of a

65
farm houses, nearly every one of which is surrounded by an Orchard in full bloom, forming a locality the most beautiful seen in Oregon;  At that distance came to the Coast Fork, which I crossed in a skiff this stream is fifty yds wide and unites with the Willamette some four miles below, the two rivers can be traced by the line of timber bordering them, which consists principally of Cottonwood

    From this place to Eugene City the Road leads through some level prarie, but as you near the city it runs over over [sic] rolling land timbered with Oak, among which you will see handsome farms and farm houses until you reach the suberbs [sic] of the City where I arrived at about two P.M. My shoulder had become painful from walking and I made direct to the most convenient Hotel to obtain rest before I sought out a Surgeon to perform the operation of putting things right
     Being a Stranger in this town, and not knowing who to consult, I asked the advice of several and was in every instance, referred to Dr Ramsey upon whom I called, as soon as I felt able to do so
     He immediately pronounced my shoulder out of place and torn loose from the Collar bone, and the Collar bone also broken, and immediately made preparations to replace them.  I was first seated upon the floor with by back to the wall, and laying hold of my arm, with his foot under the Armpit, he asked the assistance of several individuals to assist him; when all was ready they sprang back with a force that I thought would tear my arm off, and did not slaken [sic] [crossed out:  until] for a few moments, when position was changed

68
people for traffick, and do not hesitate to sell their wives or children, a boy or girl of six or eight years of age may be bought for about 10 dollars, while a Squaw of marriageable age is held at about $20.00

     A wife at about the same price, unless she is a [?Caltus?] one, and in that case they will give another person something to take her

Sunday May 20th

    A little over four weeks have elapsed since I had my shoulder set, it is mending rapidly, I can notice a change for the better nearly every day.
    Started today with my horses for Eugene City followed the trail on the N. side of River, and camped for the night upon a prarie of two or three acres below point lookout, called "Demijohn Prarie"

Mon 21st

    Stopped for the night at the first house at the foot of Butte Disapointment where I stopped the night of Apr 15

Tuesday 22nd

   Instead of crossing the river near this place as is generally the case in travelling up and down, I kept down on the N. side, over a country rolling, and timbered with Oaks, for 4 miles to "Fall Creek" a stream 30 yds in width, which is crossed at a good ford, you cross one or two other small creeks or sloughs soon after leaving fall Creek, and then enter a fine open prarie Country, thickly settled, and here upon these praries, I found large ripe strawberries

67
quantity of dry Cedar bark, nearby to form a temporary shelter for the night.
Thurs May 10th

      It rained all night, and looks dismal today, the bushes wet;  I kept the trail on the N. side of the River, and arrived at the N. Fork, which I was obliged to wade, it was deep with a swift current, I procured a good setting pole, and started in.  I found it dificult {sic] to keep a foot hold, could only do so by fixing the pole firmly upon the bottom below me, then to take a few steps carefully, and then securing both feet, firmly braced, before removing the pole, and in this manner I succeeded in crossing to the opposite side.  I found the water very cold and waist deep
    Arrived at the scene of my misfortune about 10 A.M.    The two following days were snow squally, the ground covered to the depth of one or two inches

Mon 14th 

    Day warm, snow off the Valleys and low hills.  The Klamath Indians in this vicinity (before referred to) as the weather is getting warm, may be seen roaming over the praries, in every direction and at almost any time of day, in search of Cammas, a bulbous root resembling a small onion, and when roasted contains much nutriment  tasting something like a sweet -potatoe
    They are a poor miserable race subsist principally by root digging and hunting, they kill a good many deer some bear and other animals, the skins of which are dressed by the squaws and are traded to the whites for almost any thing that is offered.  they are a great

70
on Fern Ridge, to make the trip by the Northern route, more commonly called the "Old Emigrant Road

     From the upper, or south end of Fern Ridge you have a distant view of the "three Sisters" three noted snowy peaks in the Cascade Mts, and from any part of the Ridge you have a view of "Marys Peak" a Mountain in the "Coast Range" standing a few miles S.W. of Corvallis.  and as that place is on my route, I can locate it very nearly by the peak referd [sic] to.  it is not a mountain of perpetual snow, but the highest in the vicinity, from this distance (40 miles) it has the appearance of a Bald Mountain
    The first five miles was down the level country lying on the right side of the Long Tom, through a thick settled region.  to the crossing. known as "Taylors Bridge" where the stream is crossed upon a good frame bridge, and as you cross you enter upon the great thoroughfare, leading South to California.  The Long Tom at this crossing is about thirty feet wide dark muddy water, running through a strip of heavy timbered bottoms some seven or eight miles to the Eastward.  From Taylors Bridge, to the Town of Monroe, about 15 miles, the Country might be called gently rolling, principally prarie and thickly settled.    about one mile before you reach Monroe you cross the the [sic] line between Lane and Benton Counties              Monroe is a pretty little place situated on the left bank of Long Tom, and contains about one dozen buildings.  The Long Tom bottoms are timbered, with Oak, Ash, Maple, Willow Crab Apple, and a variety of small shrubbery

69
in abundance, surpassing any before seen in Oregon

     In this country these berries grow upon low vines, and often are formed under the surface and push the dirt from them as they increase in growth
    After travelling  down the River for 17 miles, through pretty valleys, and fine rolling praries, and some timbered ridges, thickly settled all the way, arrived at the little town of "Springfield" situated on the right bank of the river three miles from Eugene City,   Springfield consists of about a dozen buildings and is apparently doing a pretty little business, cross the River at this place on a ferry Boat and in about one hours time enter Eugene City
    The Country in the Willamette Valley is much pleasanter at this season of the year than at any other, the swales and sloughs upon the praries are dry, grass and other vegetation at its full growth, the praries are covered with the handsomest flowers the world affords of all varieties, of all shape and color.  Strawberries are plenty and ripe in the swales and low lands the wild rose grows plentifully and at this time is in full bloom, and every thing seems pleasant..
    Stayed in the neighborhood of Eugene [crossed out: for] until the morning of June 11th when the season being so far advanced that I did not deem it safe to make the trip to Walla Walla via the head of Willamette and Des Chutes Rivers, on account of the Indians who at this season of the year are scattered over a much larger scape of country, than during the winter season, consequently much more danger, therefore I set out from the residence of my acquaintan [sic]

72
running nearly parallel to the Willamette

    Passing Albany three miles and you intersect the great Thoroughfare, running N. and S. through Oregon, on the E. side of the Willamette.
    Following this thoroughfare about 5 miles over a pretty Country and you arrive at the ferry on the Santiam, a pretty stream of clear water about 125 yds wide, and is one of the principle tributaries on the E of the Willamette, and is the county line between Linn and Marion Cos 
    Cross the R. into the little town of "Jefferson City" situated on a level tract of timbered land, containing about 40 buildings, from this the road leads off in a N. Easterly course, to the town of "Sublimity of distance of 15 miles, through gently rolling country, timbered but beautifully diversified with good and well cultivated farms.     Sublimity contains about 12 buildings, is situated upon an Oak ridge, appears to be a dull place, passed this place four miles and stoped for the night having travelled 36 miles

Wed June 13th

      Started early, travelled 8 miles over Oak ridges, to "Silver Creek" a stream 50 feet wide tributary to Willamette, Cross the Creek into the little town of "Silverton" a place of 25 buildings pleasantly situated upon its right bank
    At four miles from Silverton Cross "Abiqua" creek of some 20 yds wide, and four miles from that cross "Butte Creek" of about the same size which separates the Counties of Marion and "Clacamas", pass Butte Creek about

71
peculiar to Creek bottoms.   From Monroe to Corvallis 18 miles it is level, thickly settled, with the spurs of the Coast Range Mts not over four or five miles to the W. of you, and the Long Tom to your right, until you approach Corvallis and then the Willamette approaches until you enter Corvallis which is a Town beautifully situated upon its west bank, containing about 250 buildings and is the County seat of Benton Co

    As you enter the Town you Cross "Marys river a Sluggish stream of about 20 yds in width, upon a high frame bridge near its mouth,   A few miles S.W. stands Marys Peak, prominent in vicinity and a deposit of Snow upon its N.E. side

June 12th

     Left Corvallis this morning, by crossing the River on a Ferry Boat;   The River is perhaps 150 yds wide, and is the line between Benton and Lewis Cos.
     From thence to Albany in a N.E. Course of 10 miles, the Country is gently rolling, timbered, and quite thickly settled.   About ½ mile before you reach Albany, you cross the Calipooia Creek a stream of 20 yds wide;  As you enter Albany you will observe the Village Cemetery, tastefully arranged, upon the bank of the Willamette a few yards to the left of the road.
     Albany is a pretty locality, contains about 150 buildings, and is the County Seat of Linn Co.
    At this place the Country expands into wide level praries, extending from the Willamette to the Eastward for 10 or 12 miles to the Santiam River which flows at the foot of the Cascade Mts and

74
flowing N.  Cross the Creek, ascend the bluffs again, and turn more to the E. and you appear at once at the locality known all over Oregon as "Fosters," 120 m from Eugene City   
Foster has been settled here nearly ever since the first settlement of Oregon, has a good farm well improved, has made himself rich off the poor "Emigrants" who are Annually crossing the Cascade Mts.    This place is generally considered the foot of the Mts hence the importance of the place

   At three miles from Fosters, over hilly and broken country, and overtook a family that were making their way across the Mts. with a few head of Cattle & Horses, and an Ox Wagon, they had camped for the night and the day being somewhat advanced, we camped with them.   They were an interesting family group, hovering around a small fire, the day cold and wet, the man was dressed shabbily even for an Oregonian the Woman barefooted, with a Blue [?drilling"] dress and Bonnet her only clothing the youngest child, naked or wrapped in a shawl  the second with an Old shirt, the third with a pair of old drawers on, and the fourth and last, the most comical of all, had on a pair of mens pants with legs cut of [sic] to suit his length, all with their faces bedaubed with dirt, ashes, filth &c to such an extent that it would be dificult [sic] to distinguish them from Digger Indians

Friday June 15th

    A rainy morning, while the others were getting up the Stock, I succeeded in killing a fine white tailed deer, which added considerable to our Stock of provisions, as well as to that of the family, who were well pleased at the prospect of

73
three miles and you arrive at Rock Creek.  From this the Country was quite hilly and very brushy, my course being a little to the E. of N. for five miles, when I came to a creek of 30 yds in width which I forded at a rocky bar, it was rapid but not deep by consulting my pocket map, I found this to be the "Molelle' R.' a tributary to the Willamette,  The country is becoming more thinly settled, as you approach the Northward and near the Road that leads over (crossed out: of] the Cascade Mts.   From "Molelle" it is about two miles, to the next stream of some 30 feet in width upon which is a grist mill, and some little settlement around it.  crossing this creek you ascend a mountain by a gradual ascent of about 3/4 of mile to its summit, from which the road bears off N. upon a high ridge of open timber and fern land, with now and then an occupied claim, and upon this ridge I stopped for the night having travelled 35 miles;  the afternoon was quite rainy:
Thursday June 14th

    Travelled six miles over high land, and arrived at a small creek called "Clear Creek" upon which is a saw mill and several buildings around about it, here I fell in with a man from Marion Co. on his way to the "Umatilla" (in the Walla Walla County). with a Band of Cattle, and not having the necessary assistance required to drive Stock, I engaged with him to assist him to his journeys end, and after driving three miles we came to the Bluffs of "Clacamas" River, and could overlook its valley which appeared to be about one mile wide and heavily timbered, descended down into this valley, which appeared to be ¼ mile deep, to the River, which is 100 yds wide & brisk Current.  forded the River at a pretty good ford, and landed near a Saw Mill, built upon a small creek or slough.  from this ascend the high land again, and at 1 ½ m descend a steep of ¼ m to a Creek 20 yds in width

76
wider, intersperssed [sic] with large boulders, among which Conglomerates abound, but principally volcanic.   follow the R. 3 miles and cross to the opposite bank, 20 yds wide, rough rocky bottoms, and belly deep to horses, follow up stream about one mile upon the same sandy bottoms, thinly timbered with "fir" "Spruce pine" Sugar pine" "Balm of Gilead" and then ascends a hill to second bench of level and heavy timbered with "hemlock & fir.  pass the last house on the western slope of the Mts., upon this bench land, pass the house one mile and again descend to the Bottoms of sand and boulders [crossed out: again] which soon becomes very much obstructed with fallen timber, and in three or four miles you strike the south fork of Sandy, and in ¼ m cross it at an Island formed by two channels of the stream, each about 20 ft wide;  After three or four miles further over Rock & sand and dead timber, again cross the stream by a bad rocky ford, very rapid;  5 miles from this ford, leave rock and sand country and enter a heavy forest of green timber, principally hemlock.

    Soon after entering this timber, on the right hand side of the road, upon a little mossy knoll, you will observe the grave of a little Child, the head board bore a dim inscription, written with a pencil, with the initials "F.H.W." plainly carved upon it with a knife.
  Travelling through this green timber one mile and you find yourself at the foot of "Laurel Hill"
  This hill is high, Steep and rocky, and as you approach it, it appears to be nearly perpendicular and formed of loose rocks with large green timber growing all over the sides of it.

75
of a supply of fresh meat, and more particularly the Lady who acknowledged the receipt of it in a manner most pleasing and as only women can do;   We arrived at a River called "Sandy" in about 6 miles, the country cut up with cañons, this stream is about 40 yds wide and rapid, with a bad ford.  We drove our Cattle and horses across, and then went up stream about 100 yds and crossed on a foot log, where the R. is divided into two Channels, by a large Conglomerate Boulder, with logs lying from it to each bank,   Upon this R. which is very rocky, the Conglomerate occupies a prominent place among other formations.   After ascending the bluff of the R. which are some 200 ft high, and travelling one half mile on nearly level land, passing one house, you ascend a steep mountain for ¼ mile which leads off E. in the shape of a timbered ridge, for 6 miles to the"Mountain House", kept by a Frenchman & Squaw; this Ridge is known as the "Back bone" and no water to be found on it

    Pass this Establishment about one mile and you descend to level timbered land, in which we continue for one mile, crossing two pretty little Creeks, where we arrived at a preemption Camp, built of Rails & well covered with puncheons, and fearing no better locality would offer, we camped here for the night being a very little grass in the vicinity for our animals, during the night it rained some little but were kept dry by the shelter of the Rail Cabin, which alone saved us from being thoroughly wetted,    

Sat June 16th

    A wet rainy night, last night   Started early course E. and soon descended a steep hill to the Banks of Sandy, following up said stream, we found the bottoms of loose sand to become somewhat

78

    At about two miles from the summit of this last hill, on the right of the Road pass a grave of some poor Emigrant, but no inscription upon the head board, and a short distance past this we came to a good "Corall" that had been built by some former drover, and here we coralled the band for the night, and tied our horses to trees;   Since the ascent of Laurel hill, the forest of heavy green timber, Fir hemlock &c has been thickly interspersed with large Snow banks, that are at present some two or three feet deep, but the Road is pretty open, only occasionally passing over these banks, and as the snow is in a solid compact form animals walk over it very easily

Sund June 17th

    Started off on an E. course, over a rough road passing a small band of Des Chute Indians on their way to Portland, ½ m from Camp pass over a log bridge, over swampy land, and as you pass it and enter upon dry land again, you will notice to your right, upon an open spot of dry ground, the grave of a little child,  It may be distinguished by a little mound of small rock with a head board standing at the W. end of it, upon which an inscription written with a pencil had become so nearly obliterated that the following was all that I could trace out, "-----Lambert.......died September.......1852"
      After travelling about three miles over gently rolling country, over some very bad log bridges crossing many small streams of Cold water, when on the left bank of a rapid one of about 10 ft in width and near the road you will notice another grave, covered over with a log covering, upon the head board of which may be read the following  "Hannah, wife of Wm Bond

77

    The ascent, at an angle of 45º is long and tedious, upon a grade or dug road, paved and walled with large boulders and small loose rock of which the hill seems to be composed, you wind yourself up, in a zigzag manner, all the time bearing a little to the left, a good portion of the way following up a small spring branch, that gushes out near the top and runs along down the road nearly to the bottom
    It is about three fourths of a mile from the foot to the top of the hill, and from thence the road leads off passing over two or three smaller hills, steep and rocky, when you arrive at the foot of another hill as steep, but not as long as Laurel hill.  Ascended this with difficulty, and found heavily timbered country instead of the "Flowering Laurel", as had expected from the name it bore
    From the Character of these two hills and the Road thus far, it is to be wondered how that thousands of Emigrants, with families, wives and Children, their teams and wagons, have made their way successfully over this route, without meeting with misfortunes and losses, that would deter others from following in their fotsteps [sic]. but we seldom hear of any misfortunes or sufferings in these Mts any more than other Emigrant Roads are subject to
    This is the principle Emigrant Road over these Mts and has been travelled by the Emigrants from Oregons earliest settlement to the present time
   It would be pronounced impassable, by any one not accustomed to mountain roads, and many good Mountaineers, pronounce it impracticable, yet thousands of wagons have passed over it and are now passing over it every year

80

   It certainly is not far from the beholder when viewing it from this place.  It has the appearance of not being over two or three miles, but is probably 10 or 12.  It bears nearly due N. from this place, has been an active Volcano but at the present time is supposed to be extinct.  From Mt Hood, the Country is a gradual slope to the S. sufficient to cause a rapidity in the streams 
    Leaving Summit prarie, had a bad muddy road for ½ m and then for 2 m the road passes over rolling ground not bad, and desend [sic] gradually for about 2m to a little stream some 12 ft in width flowing S. this brings us down out of the region of snow.  the next mile the country is level rocky & sandy, and spruce pine timber crossing two other streams of 10 ft in width, and then again ascend to the region of Snow banks, from the top of this you descend for ¼ m on to the heads of a stream, down which the Road finds its way, through timber principally killed by fires, followed this Creek down 8 or 9 miles, with a gradual descent, crossing it six times, and finally camping on its right bank at the last crossing where it is deep, rapid and 20 ft wide, for the last 2 miles the timber has been Spruce pine and the ground sandy & Rocky, here for the first time noticed a new species of wood, very much resembling the Tamarack of the Northern States
   From this Camp Mt Hood is in full view bearing N.W.

Mon June  18th

     Travelled down this Stream about 4 m, crossing it five times.  Sandy soil, timber Fir, Spruce-pine and the Tamarack referred to yesterday then leaving the Creek to the right of us & turn North.

79
died Sept. 15th 1853, aged 32, from Marion Co Iowa"

    Surely a lonely grave and in a lonely place, upon the banks of a pretty stream flowing from the perrennial [sic] Snows of Mt "Hood" the highest Mountain in North America, in the midst of a thick forest of Hemlock & fir, upon the summit of one of the most rugged chain of Mts upon this Coast:  sleeps in peace and quietude the mortal remains of Hannah Bond, but it is sweet consolation to know that the spirit of the departed are as happy on the desert or in the Mountains, far from Civilization, as in the presence of families and friends and every thing that is near and dear to them in life.  the presence of God is everywhere
    Passing this grave a few yds, and you enter upon swampy land, with many log bridges in bad condition for crossing, in the midst of which is an opening to your right, which widens into a prarie of some ¼ m in extent covered with fine grass although very short, the snow not being off long enough yet for it to grow.   this is called "Summit prarie" it is wet and swampy all round it, and innumerable small streams flowing past it, all making their way S.   The Timber around it is fir, hemlock and Spruce
   This is supposed to be the summit of the Cascade Mts and is the line between Clacamas and "Wasco" Cos
    From this prarie you have a splendid view of Mt Hood, a high conical mass of snow.  14000 ft above the level of the sea, and probably 8 or 10,000 ft above the surrounding Mts, the thick growth of Evergreen timber can be traced up its acclivity, gradually appearing less until finaly [sic] it is completely buried in the snow,  It is probably a solid mass of Volcanic Rock and in some perpendicular places that are visible it has the appearance of Basalt
