Monday, June 24th 1861

     Having made the necessary arrangements for a trip to Walla Walla with a band of Cattle, I set out from the Claim of Cyrus Heddin, in the precinct of Elkton, Umpqua County, Oregon, [crossed out: on] with a band of 107 head of Cattle. and the Necessary horses and pack animals.. To give assistance in the first days drive. I had besides William Patterson..James M. Merrick and Daniel Test. (my men employed) P.P. Palmer. A.G. Langdon Julius Chamberlain Daniel Dimmick, John Mulkey and G. Mehl..   Among the many scenes and excitements of starting a band of Cattle, it is frequently more advantageous to a drover to keep his band together, at the starting, than at any other time on the Road.. We had remarkably good luck and reached the Ferry on the Umpqua River, and succeeded in Swimming the Cattle to the otherside [sic] during the afternoon. without much detention or loss of time.   The Cattle swam badly,, by striking down stream and landing at intervals on either side
   Stayed in the Kellogg bend until Thursday June 27th.
   When we set out at 9 A.M. The Road was brushy, but Cattle drove well, and we reached Green Valley in the P.M. & Camped near Beazley
   Lost a Cow to day

Friday June 28
Reached Yoncalla in the P.M. and camped in Burts Lane,

230
Thursday July 4th
Drove towards Corvallis. and Camped 10 miles from it
Friday July 5th
Reached Corvallis and Swam our Cattle across the Willamette River at this place.  they swam very badly, getting in the middle of the Stream, and drifting down Stream for about one mile before we succeeded in landing them 
Saturday July 6th
Drove past Albany and camped on Oak Creek a small tributary of the Calipooia which empties in to the Willamette a short distance above Albany..  To day we had a fair view of the "Sisters".. Mt Hood. Mt Jefferson, and Mt St Helens of Washington Territory
Sunday July 7th

  Reached the South fork of "Santiam" a stream of 50 yds wide, flowing through thick timbered bottoms, forded this Stream and camped about 2 miles from it

Monday July 8th
Passed the little Town of "Scio" and thence to the North fork of Santiam, a stream of 60 yds wide where we swam our cattle and ferried our horses.. Camped on the Sublimity Road
Tuesday July 9th

   The Road was very brushy to day. we made a short drive, passing Sublimity

229
Saturday June  29th

   Left Yoncalla.  Crossed the Calipooia Mountain, and camped in the Siuslaw Valley

Sunday June 30th

   Made a Short drive of 8 miles and Camped on "Spencer Creek", a small Tributary to "Long Tom"

Monday July 1st

    Drove over to the lower End (North End) of "Fern Ridge" and camped on the "Kiota" another branch, that empties into "Long Tom" a short distance below us

Tuesday July 2d
Lay in Camp to day, T "Three Sisters" and "Diamond peak" are visible from this locality some 75 or 100 miles distant, the "Sisters" nearly due East (see page 70) and "Diamond Peak about S.E.
[sketch of mountain labeled: Diamond Peak]
Wednesday July 3d

   Drove about 10 Miles and camped at Mill Irons on the Eugene City & Corvallis Road

232
Tuesday July 16th
The Cattle drove badly over the sandy & rocky road.  reached the foot of "Laurel Hill" at Noon.. Made the ascent in good order and at about 3 miles farther Camped and found good grass at a Marsh about one fourth of Mile to the left of the Road
Wednesday July 17th

  Made a good drive to day passed "Summit prarie" [sic] which we found to be very muddy.  some of the Cattle mired down and had to be dragged out, some few patches of snow were to be seen among the thick timber,  Corralled our Cattle on "Sandy Des Chutes"

Thursday July 18th

 McMerricks Horse and my little mule were missing, the Cattle were so thin and so near starved that we dare not spend much time in searching for them therefore we Started on and reached the open Country at "Barlows Gate" in the afternoon

Friday July 19th

  Did not move our Camp to day, McMerrick and Patterson, returned to Sandy Deschutes to search for the Horse & Mule. and succeeded in finding them and reached camp a little after dark

Saturday July 20th

  Drove about 6 Miles and camped on Rock Creek

231
Crossing "Aberqua" & "Butte" Creeks, and Camped for the night
Wednesday July 10th

   Passed over a very brushy Road to day passing through "Silverton" and travelled a few miles farther and Camped

Thursday, July 11th

   Brushy Road again today.  Camped in the Mollalle Prarie..  At this place we found a poor little Jew Peddler Stuck in a mud hole, and unable to get his horse out. which was floundering in the Mud and unable to get up,  After some little trouble, we succeeded in getting his horse on dry ground, and upon fishing his pack of Dry goods, from the mud hole found them damaged but little.

Friday July 12th

  Drove to "Clear" Creek and Camped 

Saturday 12th

   Camped at Fosters,  Road rough & brushy

Sunday July 14th

   Started pretty early, reached "Sandy" about noon. and the "Mountain [?] at 3 PM & Camped there

Monday July 15th

  Arrived at second crossing of sandy and found our cattle to drive very badly over and along the sand and roky [sic] bottoms of said Stream,  we camped on "Zig Zag" the East fork of "Sandy"

234
Thursday July 25th
Had a very hot day, reached "John Days" River at Sundown
Friday July 26th
Forded the River, and followed up rock Creek some four or five miles and camped
Saturday July 27th
Lay in Camp until 3 P.M. then Started out and reached Willow Creek 24 miles distant about 2 oclock in the Morning, found Cattle to drive better during the Night than in the heat of the day
Sunday July 28th
Lay in Camp
Monday July 29th
Drove on, and camped at the upper "Well Springs"
Tuesday July 30th
Reached "Butter Creek". wind high and road dusty to-day
Wednesday July 31st
Day hot, road very dusty.  Camped on the "Umpuatilla" [sic}
Thursday Aug 1st
Travelled to the Upper Umatilla & camped
Friday Aug 2d
Reached "Wild Horse" Creek. and concluded to stop here for a while. and see what disposition I could make of my Cattle &c
Wednesday Aug 3d [sic]
Patterson and Merrick set out for

233
Sunday July 21st

 Daniel Test left us this Morning for his home in Umpqua, having only engaged to accompany us this far..  I regretted his departure very much. for he was one of our best Men, but as the Country is open the balance of the distance, and the Cattle have become so accustomed to driving. that we will not likely have much more dificulty [sic] in driving..Left Camp at 10 A.M. and reached "Tyghe" Creek and Camped 4 or 5 miles below the ford day hot and rosd dusty

Monday July 22d
Day hot.  Cattle drove badly, reached the bluffs of "Des Chutes' River.. Swam our Cattle at the old Ferry landing about ¼ Mile below the Bridge.  Camped on the opposite Side of the River, on a Small branch putting in at this place
Tuesday July 23d
Ascended the Bluffs and soon reached the Muddy spring five miles from this where we found water for our own use but none for out Stock, stopped here until late in the P.M. and then set out and at Midnight, camped at the Spring in the long hollow
Wednesday July 24th
Lay in Camp

[no page number]
direct from the mines. formerly from Calipooia precinct Umpqua County and was on his way to Tyghe Creek, soon after starting out we were overtaken by a black horse which followed us. at the bridge across Des Chutes River, we made an unsuccessful attempt to pawn him for our toll failing in that we proceeded on the horse in company, the bridge helper attempted to corall him but was unable to do so;  As we reached Tyghe Creek we noticed a newly made grave  on the left side of the road near the place of our camp of July 21st as we were on our way up, It proved to be the grave of a man found dead, at this point on the 12th of August. killed by the Indians on or about the 21st of July, and from the suspicious actions of a number of Indians observed at that place at the time of our encampment, am led to believe that the murder was committed upon the day we arrived here with our cattle on the 21st July,  At the crossing of Tyghe Creek my comrade Smith left me, but the stray horse was anxious to follow and baffled all attempts to secure him in a caroll,  [sic] passing "Barlows Gate" a few rods I met two Indians who claimed the pony.  they were very anxious to sell or trade him. said they had lost him the day before on Des Chutes River, I was not prepared to say but the horse belonged to the Indians but certainly did not like their appearance and the manner in which they set up their claim, so I conceived a plan to rid myself of the two Indians and add a couple more horses to mine,,  So dismounting, at their request, to the better negotiate a trade, with my horses secure by me, I changed position, so as my rifle, as it lay across my arm was bearing upon the two "poor Indians" who were at that time in direct range, and then quietly cocking my gun as it lay on my arm, I as quietly pulled trigger, with the intention of killing the two savages at a fire, But wise calculations sometimes fail. and mine also failed in this case for the cap exploded much to the relief of the poor fellows, but very much to my own mortification,,  The Indians were suddenly aroused to a sense of the situation, and one drawing a knife rushed toward me, I dropped my gun and bridle reins from my hands

235
for Walla Walla to-day, leaving me by myself with the band -
Friday Aug 8
They returned from Walla Walla and camped with me.
Saturday Aug 9
They set out this morning for Umpqua via "Dalles City" and I am again left alone.
October 8
Having disposed of my cattle [added: by renting them out for the winter] and made arrangements to leave this upper County I set out for Umpqua and camped on the upper Umatillah.
Oct 9
Camped on Butter Creek
Oct 10
Pass the lower Well Spring, camp on Willow C
Friday Oct 11
Arrived at Cedar Spring at noon, passed over the hill to John Daye River, passed John Daye River about 4 miles, and camped at a very good spring situated in a deep ravine? to the left of the Road
Saturday Oct 12
Travel through the long hollow and camp at the Spring five miles from Des Chutes
Sunday Oct 13
This morning I was overtaken by a man by the name of Mr Smith

[no page number]
I wintered at Elkton in the winter of 1861 &62  Winter set in early and was cold, blustering and heavy rains prevailed.  On the 2d of Dec. The Umpqua River was higher by several feet than ever before since the Vally [sic] was settled by the Whites;  Heavy rains continuing and on the 9th the River rose fully 20 feet higher than the high water of a week previous 

    All the bottom lands were over flowed, & bridges. fences; houses, barns, Stacks of grain &c filled the River all day, as the rapid Current heaved them on towards the Ocean;  A vast deal of Stock was drowned. hundreds of houses and barns were swept away the Inhabitants fleeing to the hills
   The little town of Scottsburg was entirely swept away, the Most of the farmers living in the River bottom land. losing everything houses & Improvements.  Hay grain & Stock,  Bridges were carried away & Road badly torn to pieces everywhere;   The loss to the Umpqua Valley was frightful.   Immediately following the Freshet, Came a heavy Storm & fall of snow of about 12 inches deep. and cold freezing weather prevailed for about one month. destroying nearly all the stock in the Country which had escaped the flood:  I was calculating to

and backed off from the plan, at the same time drawing my Rev[olver] a Colts six shooter "Navy" size, the advancing Indian snatched my gun and with the breech of it aimed a blow at my head, with intent to knock me down with it before the pistol could be cocked & fired, and he came near accomplishing [it]  never did mans fingers move more nimbly than mine, and at the instant that the pistol fired the breech of the gun descended upon my left arm and head with such force as to knock me down, I was not stunned and jumping up I [?saw?] the Indian stumble and fall near me with the bullet in his breast by this time the other had mounted his horse, and fled for the timber.  I fired two shots but did not bring him down, his [?comrade's?] horse followed him, I examined the "poor" fellow & found him really dead, so picking up my gun whose failure to perf[orm] duty had So near proved fatal to me, I found that the blow had nearly broke the breech off, having checked it to suc[h] an extent that could not safely carry it without first {?] it in order to give it firmness, My head pained me some little, and quite a bump was appearing upon it as well as u[pon] my arm below the elbow, but was highly satisfied w[ith] the result, and heartily congratulate myself to think that "it was no worse", proceeded on camped in the Mountains, after which I soon reached the settlements on the west side passed the Willamette Valley Via "French Prarie" Salem, Corvall[is] and reached Elkton in Umpqua County about last of the Month

return to Walla Walla in the early spring and branch out into the Stock business as well as I was able to but the severity of the Winter put a heavy damper on my future prospects. and soon after the snow melted off gloomy accounts from up the Columbia began to reach us and with hundreds of others who had stock in that Country. Our guns were immediately brought into requisition and for a few moments terrible execution was done to our ammunition.. and after the smoke had cleared away and the surviving Elk had got out of reach of our guns up the high Mountain side,, we found that we had succeeded in killing two of them, both proved to be females heavy with young, and [?poor?] they would weigh about 350 lbs each.

  We camped at this place and relished our [?]    Elk Meet [sic] first rate

Tuesday May 20th 1862

   Had a roaring fire all night, which was a good substitute for blankets, got an early start this morning,, continuing up Stream on the left side of the Creek. we found the Mountains More abrupt. and the bottoms More Narrow, in many places had dificulty [sic] in getting along the steep Mountain side.  At 10 A.M. we arrived at the foot of a foaming Cascade or Cataract where the Creek was rushing along over Rocks & Boulders of large size, form chasms. caves and beautiful perpendicular falls of from 5 to 20 feet and in other places running under. these large boulders almost hiding the Creek for a few feet then tumbling over precipitous rocks, forming Scenery beautiful. wild and romantic in the extreme, following up this Cataract on a curve to the left, for about one fourth of  mile, and you find a smooth stream again and about 250 yds from the head of this Cataract we reach the Lake. with only the lower end

241
Trip to "Loon Lake
By L. L. Williams
Monday May 19th 1862
Set out from Scottsburg in Company with Job Watfield and Joseph Peters for a trip of exploration & hunting, to a Lake situated in the Mountains to the South of Scottsburg, from which flows Mill Creek a stream of some 15 or 20 yds wide, which empties into the Umpqua about 5 miles below Scottsburg

   Much has been said concerning this lake by Indians, and the few whites that have visited it but, No one has been able to obtain any definite knowledge of it or its locality
   From the Mouth of "Mill Creek we took our Boat up stream some two miles, and was stopped at this place by rapids that checked our further progress by water..  Here we left our Boat and made our way up stream on the left hand side (right bank) of said Creek found the Creek to be Crooked and rapid with narrow bottoms from ten to one hundred yards wide, covered with Salmon brier bush vine Maple &c.  Elk and Bear tracks were plenty, and Beaver and Otter inhabited the stream..  Made slow progress clambering along the Creek, over fallen timber, rock &c crossing a small branch of 2 or 3 feet in width occasionally, when in the afternoon having travelled about seven Miles, we discovered a Small band of seven Elk gazing at us from the opposite side of the Creek about 75 yds off

[page from a book covering most of journal page 244 shows a painting of a loon with no text]
[five lines of journal page not covered by picture]
to be extensive, and of rich fertile soil.

  We left our raft at this place and made our way up stream on the right hand side of the Creek upon a narrow ridge between the River or Creek and a small

243

   visible,, which is about one fourth of a mile wide, and has the appearance of a pretty sheet of Clear, deep water, surrounded by high abrupt Mountains; we travelled around to the west side of the foot of the Lake, built a Raft for Navigation tomorrow, killed a large Elk for Supper, and Camped    After Calculating our distance we found ourselves about 13 Miles from the Mouth of the Creek in a course about S.S.E. which located the Lake about 8 or 10 Miles nearly due south from Hatfields prarie,  Our Courses were carefully taken with a pocket Compass, and every distance carefully estimated, and for further reference see Map on page 224
   Elk, Bear, Beaver & Otter appear to be very plenty, deer are not as plenty as in other localities nearer the settlements.
   The Creek at the foot of the Lake is about 50 feet wide, and of nearly the same width to tide water near its mouth, only a few branches putting into it, one Stream or fork about 30 feet wide emptying in from the North about four miles below the Lake, is the principle river or branch

Wednesday May 21st
Last Night for the first time in Oregon, we listened to the long shrill Cry of the Loon an aquatic bird peculiar to all the "Lakes of the North"   We set out this morning on our raft of logs to circumnavigate the Lake kept the right Land shore, taking the

244
[reproduction of the page cuts off the left margin of the text]
[?]anders as carefully as the circumstances would [per]mit ,,  Saw the Loons that we had heard [?]king during the night, and Jo Peters very [soon] discovered their nest. consisting of two [?] deposited upon a bog of grass growing [?up]on a Snag protruding from the Water. the [?eggs] are very pretty of a brown speckeled [sic] color [?] large as small Goose Eggs,, Considered the [?] prize and will take them home.

  From the fact that Loons inhabit this [lo]nely place, Mr Hatfield suggested the [n]ame of "Loon Lake",,  In our progress [u]p the Lake,, we saw a few ducks, and a [li]ttle band of Elk on the Mountains to [o]ur right, but had no occasion to go [a]fter them.  We reached the head of the [La]ke at noon, and by our estimate found it to be [a]bout three miles long and about one fourth [mile in] width, we run our craft into the inlet [at] the head of the lake about ¼ mile and was [s]topped by a large deposit of drift wood extend[i]ng from bank to bank, which seems to be [af]loat or nearly so, with vegetation and small [s]hrubbery, springing up from it,,  The stream [is] deep, of some sixty feet in width, with no [per]ceptable current,  Wide bottoms of timber [?] border this stream, and appear [to] be extensive, and of rich fertile soil.
   We left our raft at this place and made [our] way up stream on the right hand [side] of the Creek upon a narrow ridge [be]tween the River or Creek and a small

246
was bearing west, but its general course from the mouth is S.S.E.   The Bottoms as far as seen appear to be of a uniform width rich soil, heavy timbered, with the largest Maple, Ash and Myrtle that I have seen in the Country,  Scattering firs of large dimensions, some 8 or 10 ft in diameter were found upon these bottoms, the largest one Measured was
31½ feet in circumference
Thursday May 22d
The majority of our little party being satisfied with our explorations, we concluded to make our way homewards, travelled down the Creek upon the opposite side from that travelled yesterday, always following well beaten Elk & Bear trails,,  We had not travelled far, when a very large bear was observed about 60 yds off. with breast to us. a well directed shot sent him off, at a head long pace, with a bullet in the Center of his breast, we followed and soon overtook, and dispatched his bearship, saw two Elk near where the Bear was killed, had no occasion to shoot them, we reached our raft at 10 A.M. and continued our Meanders down on the opposite side of the Lake, to complete he survey of it as correctly as convenient,,  We reached the foot of Lake at 2 P.M.    This is a pretty sheet of water deep, and with [?Cold] shores, surrounded  with high abrupt mountains, covered with

245
pond just to our right, in which was a few ducks.  this pond is about 200 yds wide nearly round, and covered with the Yellow pond lillies,,  Around this pond and on both sides of the Creek in the Vicinity, the brush, which is principly Salmon brier is very dense, so much so, as to assume the character of of [sic] a jungle,,  Bear trails and Elk trails are extending through these jungles in every direction

    Passing this little pond, we find the bottoms more open, and the Elk sign more plenty; beautiful level land, rich & fertile extending for ½ mile or more on each side of the stream timbered with Maple, Myrtle Ash, following the leading Elk trail up stream, we very soon came upon a place, where the panthers had killed an Elk, the greater part of which was eaten up and the remainder buried
    We soon started a band of Elk, but did not see them,,  After following up Stream in a course S.S.E. [?whi] found a place for our encampment, upon the left bank (right side) of the Creek, with a wet marsh of two or three hundred yards in extent a few rods to our right, just above this spot the Mountain puts down to the Creek. with a thorough beaten Elk trail over the spur to the level bottom just above,,  we travelled up the Creek about three miles further and then returned to our Camp
   At the termination of our trip the Creek

272
[written vertically on the page]
It was afterwards found (in August 1866)  that Loon Lake was 102 feet deep at a point near the center of the Lake, sounded by me
L.L. Williams

247
burnt timber &c,,  had no method of ascertaining the depth of Water in the Lake, but found it too deep for our setting poles nearly all the distance around it, even within a few feet of the Shore,,  This Lake is formed by an eruption of Nature, throwing the Mountain across the Stream at its foot thus  causing the water to raise and force its way through, forming the foaming Cataract, below the Lake,,  The only formation among the rocks and Cliffs that I have seen, or been able to discover is the Sand Rock so peculiar to the Coast Country,,   We left the Lake at 3 P.M. and made our way down stream 4 miles and camped at the mouth of the Stream of 30 ft wide which empties in at that point
Friday May 23d
We soon reached our first camp on the Creek of the 19th and found two Bears, in posession [sic] of our dead Elk succeeded in killing one, a Medium size and poor,,  Reached our Boat in due time, and arrived at Scottsburg at 4 P.M. at at [sic] Hatfields at 6, considering ourselves amply paid, for our ever to be remembered and interesting trip to "Loon Lake"
L. L. Williams
